title: Configure the Enterprise Service Management mobile app
content:
The suite provides a mobility solution for SMA that's based on a native mobile app published on Google Play and App Store. Before end users can use the mobile app to do their daily work, the suite administrator must set up the mobility solution.

Prerequisites

  • An access server is already set up if your organization is using a DMZ network. For details, see Configure a load balancer (reverse proxy server) for applications. If you set up the suite on AWS, you can use public VPC as DMZ.
  • The suite is already installed.

After the suite installation, the suite administrator can perform the following tasks to set up the mobile app so that end users can use the mobile app in their daily work. 

Enable the mobile app

By default, the ability to log in to SMA using the Enterprise Service Management mobile app is enabled. See Mobile app settings.

After the mobile app is installed, the device information will be registered in Google Firebase automatically. With the mobile push notification enabled, the suite firstly sends the push notifications to the Google Firebase server. Then, Google Firebase sends these push notifications to users' Smartphones (for both iOS and Android devices) according to the device information.  You can enable or disable the mobile push notifications from the Service Management Agent interface. See the Enable/disable suite mobile notifications from notification templates section below.

Configure the request forms in mobile app agent interface

To define the forms in the agent interface of the mobile app, go to Service Management > Studio > Forms. The following request forms are provided for the Enterprise Service Management mobile app:

Note: After you update the form in Service Management, you need to restart the mobile app for the changes to take effect.

  • Mobile Request New form: Form used only in the mobile app for creating New Requests records.
    Note: This form isn't in use by this mobile release. The related feature is under development and will be available in a future release. 
  • Mobile Request Detail form: Form used only in the mobile app for viewing and editing the details of a Request record.
  • Mobile Request Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for Request record previews.
  • Mobile Request Card form: Form used only in the mobile app for viewing details of a Request record in a list view.
    Note: This form isn't in use by this mobile release. The related feature is under development and will be available in a future release. 
  • Mobile ActualService Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for actual service previews.
  • Mobile Change Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for actual change previews.
  • Mobile Device Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for device previews.
  • Mobile Device Detail form: Form used only in the mobile app for viewing and editing the details of a Device record.
    Note:
    - Avoid adding M2M fields when you edit the Mobile Device Detail form, because users can't edit these M2M fields in the mobile app.
    - The following forms for Device records are still in use by the mobile app for CI editing:
    • hardware form
    • software form
    • financial form
    • network form
  • Mobile Incident Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for incident previews.
  • Mobile InfrastructurePeripheral Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for infrastructure & peripheral previews.
  • Mobile InfrastructurePeripheral Detail form: Form used only in the mobile app for viewing and editing the details of an Infrastructure & Peripheral record.
    Note:
    -     Avoid adding M2M fields when you edit the Mobile InfrastructurePeripheral Detail form, because users can't edit these M2M fields in the mobile app.
    - The financial form for Infrastructure & Peripheral records is still in use by the mobile app for CI editing.
  • Mobile License Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for license previews.
  • Mobile Problem Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for problem previews.
  • Mobile SystemElement Preview: Form used only in the mobile app for system element previews.
  • Mobile Task Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for task previews.
  • Mobile Task Detail form: Form used only in the mobile app for viewing and editing the details of a task.
  • Mobile Release Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for release record previews.
  • Mobile Person Preview form: Form used only in the mobile app for person record previews.

The following data type isn't supported in the mobile form design:

  • Enum-type for data domain

The following items aren't supported in the mobile form design:

  • Tooltip: The text that appears when you move the pointer over the field.
  • Placeholder: The text that appears when the field is empty. You can use this to give instructions or reminders to users
  • Encrypted: If selected, the field is encrypted and can only be viewed by members of the selected encryption domain. Only relevant for fields of type MEDIUM_TEXT, LARGE_TEXT, and RICH_TEXT.


Configure login page expiration time and session persistence

You can modify the login page expiration time and a session’s duration with the following parameters:

  • idm_mobile_token_lifetime_minutes: Persistent session time.
  • idm_mobile_request_token_lifetime_minutes: Login page expiration time.

If you want to apply new values to the token on mobile, use the following commands:

kubectl patch cm idm-config -n <namespace> -p '{"data":{"idm_mobile_token_lifetime_minutes":"<the value of lifetime for token in minutes(it’s 20160 by default)>"}}' 
kubectl patch cm idm-config -n <namespace> -p '{"data":{"idm_mobile_request_token_lifetime_minutes":"<the value of lifetime for request token in minutes(it’s 120 by default)>"}}'
kubectl scale deployment idm -n <namespace> --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment idm -n <namespace> --replicas=<the original number of pod for idm>

For example,

kubectl patch cm idm-config -n itsma1 -p '{"data":{"idm_mobile_token_lifetime_minutes":"40320"}}'
kubectl patch cm idm-config -n itsma1 -p '{"data":{"idm_mobile_request_token_lifetime_minutes":"240"}}'
kubectl scale deployment idm -n itsma1 --replicas=0
kubectl scale deployment idm -n itsma1 --replicas=1

If you use SAML for authentication, you must send a POST request in Postman with the following settings, otherwise the idm_mobile_token_lifetime_minutes parameter can't work properly.

  • URL: https://<external access host>/idm-service/idm/v0/api/token/request_token

  • Add a Content-Type header and set the value as application/json.

  • In the Authorization tab, set type as Basic Auth and input the Username and Password values.
    To get the Username ans Password values:
    Firstly, run the following commands to get the ADMIN_INTERGRATION_USERNAME and IDM_TRANSPORT_USER_PASSWORD_SECRET_KEY value.
    kubectl exec -it <IDM Pod> -n <IDM pod namespace> -c idm bash
    env | grep transport
    Then, you can run the following command to get the Password value:
    get_secret idm_transport_admin_password_secret_key
    Here's an example, where the Username value is the ADMIN_INTERGRATION_USERNAME value and the Password value is the PASS value shown below:
  • Add the following parameters under the Body tab:
    {
    "return_uri": "https://<external access host>/saw/ess?TENANTID=xxxxxxxx",
    "tenant": "<Tenant ID>",
    "clientType": "mobile"
    }
  • Click Send.

Replace the out-of-box suite Nginx certificate

The out-of-box Nginx certificate in the suite is signed by a private CA. You may want to replace the certificate with your own one, which is signed by your corporate root CA or a third-party root CA. For more information about how to replace the out-of-box Nginx certificate for the suite, see Replace the certificate for the suite.

If you don't do this or if your corporate root CA is a private CA, when users attempt to log in to the suite using the mobile app, the HTTPS connections are considered "untrusted" by Android and thus blocked. If this is the case, users need to import the private root CA certificate to their mobile device by following Google’s instructions: https://support.google.com/nexus/answer/2844832.

Enable suite mobile notifications

If your organization is using a proxy server to access the Internet, you can follow the instructions below to enable the suite to send the push notifications through Firebase message service. These push notifications are then sent to user's Smartphones (for both iOS and Android).  

If your organization isn't using a proxy server to access the Internet, this task isn't needed.

Before you proceed, make sure that the mobile app is working correctly. 

You can repeat the following procedure if the proxy settings are changed.

  1. Log in to the suite control plane node.
  2. Run the following command: 
    kubectl get deployment  itom-xruntime-platform  -n `kubectl get namespaces -o=custom-columns=NAME:.metadata.name --no-headers |grep itsma` -o yaml  >/tmp/itom-xruntime-platform.yaml
  3. Edit the /tmp/itom-xruntime-platform.yaml file as follows:
    1. Modify the section from
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
      to
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       value: '<proxy server address>'
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
       value: '<proxy server port number>'
      For example:
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       value: 'proxy.yourcompany.com'
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
       value: '8080'
      Use the Spacebar key instead of the Tab key to align the first letter of 'value' to the first letter of 'name' on the line above. Also, remember to put the proxy server address and port number within single quotation mark.
    2. Save the file.
  4. Run the following command to apply the changes. 
    kubectl replace --force -f /tmp/itom-xruntime-platform.yaml
     
    This stops the suite services for several minutes. We recommend that you make such changes during non-business hours.
  5. Run the following command: 
    kubectl get deployment  itom-xruntime-platform-offline  -n `kubectl get namespaces -o=custom-columns=NAME:.metadata.name --no-headers |grep itsma` -o yaml  >/tmp/itom-xruntime-platform-offline.yaml
  6. Edit the /tmp/itom-xruntime-platform-offline.yaml as follows:
    1. Modify the section from
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
      to
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       value: '<proxy server address>'
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
       value: '<proxy server port number>'
      For example:
      - name: GCM_PROXY_HOST
       value: 'proxy.yourcompany.com'
       - name: GCM_PROXY_PORT
       value: '8080'
      Use the Spacebar key instead of the Tab key to align the first letter of 'value' to the first letter of 'name' on the line above. Also, remember to put the proxy server address and port number within single quotation mark.
    2. Save the file.
  7. Run the following command to apply the changes. 
    kubectl replace --force -f /tmp/itom-xruntime-platform-offline.yaml
     
    This stops the suite services for several minutes. We recommend that you make such changes during non-business hours.
  8. Wait for the changes to be applied. Run the following command to verify if the suite is up and running: 
    kubectl get pods   -n `kubectl get namespaces -o=custom-columns=NAME:.metadata.name --no-headers |grep itsma` |grep xruntime

    All items should be Running.
  9. Run the following command and check if the proxy host and port are configured correctly: 
    kubectl get deployment  itom-xruntime-platform  -n `kubectl get namespaces -o=custom-columns=NAME:.metadata.name --no-headers |grep itsma` -o yaml

Enable/disable suite mobile notifications from notification templates

You can enable or disable the mobile push notifications from each notification templates:

  1. Go to Service Management Agent interface.
  2. From the main menu, select Administration > Configuration > Studio > Notifications
  3. Select a record type.
    Note: By default, the mobile notifications are only enabled in the Task Approval related templates for Task record types.
  4. Select a notification template.
  5. Go to the Mobile app tab. Enable or disable the mobile app notification as required.
  6. Save the change.

CA certificate Setup 

The setup step is required only if your company uses a private CA to issue the Service Portal’s certificate, and therefore the HTTPS connection is considered "untrusted" by Android and then blocked. Skip this step if your company uses a trusted certificate for Service Portal. For information about how to replace the out-of-box Nginx certificate in the suite with a certificate signed by a public CA, see Replace the certificate for Service Management Automation.

As an end user, after you have the mobile app installed successfully on your Android mobile device, if your Service Portal uses a private CA certificate, you should be able to receive your company’s private CA from your IT department. The private CA is used to issue the Service Portal’s certificate, which needs to be imported into your mobile device. See instructions on Google NEXUS or instructions on Samsung Galaxy.

The steps for certificate import may vary on different devices, please follow your device’s user guide.
